title: How to Get Rid of Onion-Smelling Body Odor

steps.title: Wash your body with antibacterial soap daily.
steps.content: Wash your body with antibacterial soap daily. Antibacterial soap kills odor-causing bacteria. Take a shower or bath every day to clean any odor-causing bacteria on your skin. Lather an antibacterial soap on a washcloth and gently scrub your body. Take a little extra time to clean areas where you sweat the most, like your armpits, feet, and groin. [1] X Research source Dry yourself off thoroughly after you finish bathing. Trapped moisture on your skin can make odor-causing bacteria grow faster or lead to skin inflammation. [2] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Apply clinical strength antiperspirant.
steps.content: Apply clinical strength antiperspirant . Antiperspirants plug your sweat glands so your underarms stay dry, and clinical-strength antiperspirants are extra effective. If you want to get rid of the onion smell in your armpits, apply antiperspirant right after you shower. Be sure to apply the antiperspirant every day to control your underarm odors . [3] X Research source

steps.title: Dust baking soda under your arms to absorb odors.
steps.content: Dust baking soda under your arms to absorb odors. If you want to naturally get rid of body odor , sprinkle a little baking soda into your hand and apply it under your arms. The baking soda will help absorb any moisture and odors throughout the day so you don’t detect any onion smell. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wear clean clothes each day.
steps.content: Wear clean clothes each day. When you get dressed in the morning, change into clothes that have been washed and smell fresh so you don’t have any residual odors. If you’ve already started to sweat and your clothes feel damp, switch into clean, dry clothes to prevent body odors from building up on your skin. [5] X Research source Remove body odors from your clothes by making a paste with baking soda and water and applying it to smelly spots. Let the paste dry before brushing it away. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Wear breathable fabrics.
steps.content: Wear breathable fabrics. Pick clothes that are made from natural fabrics, like cotton, wool, or silk, since they allow air to pass through and cool you down. If you’re exercising or staying active, choose moisture-wicking clothes that pull sweat away from your skin and prevent body odor from forming. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you’re trying to get rid of an onion smell down near your groin, avoid wearing lycra or spandex undergarments as well as yoga pants since they could trap moisture and bacteria that cause odor. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Shave excess body hair.
steps.content: Shave excess body hair. Sweat and bacteria can get trapped in your body hair, which could make body odors smell worse. [9] X Research source If you’re shaving your underarms , start by trimming long hair with an electric razor . Then, lather body wash or shaving cream on your skin and slowly use a safety razor to remove the rest of your underarm hair. [10] X Research source Be careful if you plan on shaving your pubic hair since you could accidentally cut yourself and the hair growing back in could feel itchy or become ingrown. [11] X Research source Trim with a pair of scissors instead if you don’t want to completely remove your pubic hair.

steps.title: Limit caffeine and strong-smelling foods.
steps.content: Limit caffeine and strong-smelling foods. Caffeinated drinks like coffee or soda could make you sweat more, which may make onion-smelling body odor more noticeable. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Foods like onions, garlic, curry, cabbage, broccoli, nuts, and potatoes break down in your body and could make your body odor have a stronger scent than normal. Try eliminating these foods from your diet to see if it makes body odor less noticeable. [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Alcoholic beverages can also stimulate sweating as your body breaks them down, so try to cut back on drinking.

steps.title: Practice relaxation techniques.
steps.content: Practice relaxation techniques. If you’re sweating because you feel anxious or stressed, take a deep breath in, hold it for a few seconds, and then exhale to start calming yourself down. Make it a regular habit to practice yoga or do mindful meditation to help you feel more in control over your mood so stressful situations don’t make you sweat. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Get Botox injections to help control excessive sweating.
steps.content: Get Botox injections to help control excessive sweating. Botox blocks the nerve signals in your sweat glands and prevents perspiration from forming around the injection sites. Talk to a doctor or a dermatologist to see if Botox is a good option for you. When you go in for a Botox treatment, your doctor will inject the Botox into your skin and your sweating will be under control within 3–4 days. [15] X Research source Botox lasts around 6 months, so you’ll have to continue getting regular injections to manage your sweat and body odor.

steps.title: Bacteria mixing with sweat
steps.content: Bacteria mixing with sweat While sweat is actually odorless, it quickly starts breaking down the bacteria living on your skin. As the bacteria continue to break down, they release chemicals that make unpleasant odors, known as “bromhidrosis.” The odor usually has a noticeable smell like onions, garlic, or rancid cheese. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Body odors may vary from person to person depending on the bacteria living on your skin. While some people naturally have strong body odor, others may not notice any smell when they sweat. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Foods in your diet
steps.content: Foods in your diet Strong-smelling foods like onions, garlic, Brussels sprouts, asparagus, and curry powder create more odors when they break down inside your body. Alcohol and caffeine may also make you sweat and give you noticeable body odors. [18] X Research source These foods create sulfur compounds as you digest them and release an unpleasant odor when you sweat. [19] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Stress
steps.content: Stress Whenever you’re stressed, afraid, or anxious, the apocrine glands in your underarms and groin open up and release sweat. [20] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Since you sweat more when you’re stressed, it’s more likely to break down bacteria already on your skin and create an onion smell. [21] X Research source When you’re stressed, your body releases cortisol and adrenaline that make body odor more noticeable. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Hormonal changes
steps.content: Hormonal changes If you’re going through puberty, menstruating, or dealing with menopause, your hormone levels may fluctuate and affect your ability to metabolize trimethylamines that create unpleasant odors. The change in hormones could make your body smell a little different at certain times of the month until the levels go back to normal. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Diabetes
steps.content: Diabetes If you have diabetes and don’t receive enough insulin, you may develop diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) that releases acids into your body. These acids may cause a sweet or metallic odor when you sweat. Other symptoms may include increased thirst, frequent urination, fast breathing, and muscle stiffness. [24] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source DKA can be dangerous if the acid levels are left to build up in your body, so call a doctor and seek medical attention as soon as you suspect it.

steps.title: Skin infections
steps.content: Skin infections Because skin infections are caused by bacteria, they may release unpleasant odors that could have an onion smell. [25] X Research source Along with body odor, you may also experience inflammation or a rash from a skin infection. Some of the most common infections that cause odors include: [26] X Research source Intertrigo, which is a rash caused by skin rubbing together that has a pungent discharge [27] X Research source Erythrasma, which are small scaly patches that occur where skin rubs together, like your underarms or groin [28] X Research source Trichomycosis axillaris, which causes odors and creates yellow or reddish buildup under your arms [29] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Medications
steps.content: Medications Some medications, like antidepressants, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories, blood pressure medication, and diabetes medicine all have side effects that could increase how much you sweat. When the sweat combines with the bacteria already on your skin, you may notice an unpleasant odor. [30] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: If you sweat excessively for no reason
steps.content: If you sweat excessively for no reason If you sweat while you’re sleeping or if sweat soaks through your clothes while you’re just relaxing, then it may be a sign that you have hyperhidrosis, or overactive sweat glands. It may also be a sign of a more serious underlying condition, such as metabolic issues, thyroid conditions, or a heart attack. Talk to your doctor about how frequently you’re sweating, and they may be able to prescribe medications or recommend lifestyle changes to treat the condition. [31] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: If your body odor changes
steps.content: If your body odor changes If your body odor suddenly smells different than it has in the past, it could be a sign of a new skin infection or an underlying health condition. Contact your doctor and try to describe the odor as best as you can. Schedule an appointment so your doctor can run tests and determine what caused the change. That way, you can start treating it right away. [32] X Research source

steps.title: If you notice discharge, burning, or itching
steps.content: If you notice discharge, burning, or itching If you’re trying to get rid of an onion smell down near your groin, be aware of any colored discharge or burning, itching sensations you feel since they could be signs of infection. Tell your doctor that all of the symptoms you’re feeling and make an appointment with them to diagnose the issue. [33] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
